answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some resources that you may find helpful.
Here are some projects that the Community Relations Commission of Columbus, Ohio has created by partnering with the police department.
http://crc.columbus.gov/content.aspx?id=41132
I included a similar list of programs from Burlington, NC.
http://www.ci.burlington.nc.us/index.aspx?NID=82
You can view the responsibilities for the Board of Community Relations in Toledo, OH below.
http://www.ci.toledo.oh.us/Departments/BoardofCommunityRelations/tabid/79/Default.aspx
This report is from the U.S. Department of Justice Community Relations Service about Effective guidelines for Human Relations Committees. They also discuss the relationship between public safety projects and the committee.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/2500/Guidelines_for_Effective_Human_Relations_Committees
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

answers.author: Emma Jurado
answers.text:
Hi There,
Some additional resources for you. It seems these committees are primarily advisory. Many cities also have community relations boards for their police departments. A few examples below...
http://www.miamidade.gov/advocacy/CRB_home.asp
The CRB serves an advisor to the Mayor, Board of County Commissioners and the County administration on issues impacting intergroup relations.
http://www.cleveland-oh.gov/CityofCleveland/Home/Government/CityAgencies/CommunityRelationsBoard
The board meets monthly to protect individual’s civil rights and to promote peaceful relations among and relieve tension between cultural groups. 
http://www.ci.toledo.oh.us/Departments/BoardofCommunityRelations/tabid/79/Default.aspx 
We exist to promote, empower and support citizens and neighborhoods to create social justice, equal opportunity and a harmonious environment.  We intervene in conflicts and disputes by providing investigation, facilitation and mediation services.
http://www.baltimorecity.gov/Government/BoardsandCommissions/CommunityRelations.aspx 
The Baltimore Community Relations Commission (BCRC) is the city's official Fair Employment Practice, human rights and intergroup relations agency which is responsible for combating unlawful discrimination in employment, public accommodation, housing, education, and health and welfare services based on race, color, religion, national origin, ancestry sex, physical or mental disability, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, and marital status; while promoting intergroup harmony and community tranquility by facilitating the resolution of community disputes and educating the community through intergroup relations and cultural awareness training; and assessing the status of race and intergroup relations in the city of Baltimore. 
http://www.ci.national-city.ca.us/index.aspx?page=111
It provides a forum for citizens to voice their concerns and comments about police conduct, practices and policies and improves communication between residents and the National City Police Department.

author: Kathleen Margoles
text: The City of Lake Worth has had a Community Relations Board for two years.  We contract with Palm Beach County for our public safety services.   A question has arose as to the extent of involvement the Board should have over issues pertaining to law enforcement policy that fall within the authority of the Palm Beach County Sheriffs Office.   The City Commission has asked for the CM to do research on the range of functions and duties in other Community Relations Boards, and whether having one's own police department rather than a contractual arrangement, is a factor.
title: Community Relations Boards Functions and Duties
